document: Chapter 2: The Data Science Process - Fundamentals of Data Science

questions.question: The typical data science process consists of six steps that are followed in a strict linear order.
The first step in the data science process is defining research goals and creating a project charter.
Understanding the what, why, and how of a project is part of step 1.
A project charter should not include a timeline.
Data scientists should spend minimal time understanding business goals and context.
Retrieving data is always the responsibility of the data scientist.
Data can only be found within an organization, not outside it.
Data warehouses are designed for reading and analyzing data.
Data lakes contain data in its natural or raw format.
Chinese walls are physical barriers that prevent data access.
Nielsen and GFK are companies that specialize in collecting retail industry data.
Open data is never of high quality.
Data cleansing is unimportant because models can handle dirty data effectively.
The principle 'garbage in equals garbage out' applies to data science.
Missing values are always wrong and should be deleted immediately.
Exploratory data analysis mainly uses graphical techniques.
During exploratory data analysis, you should not discover any new data anomalies.
Mike Bostock's website is useful for data exploration examples.
Model building is less focused than exploratory analysis.
Model building techniques come from machine learning, data mining, and statistics.
Building a model is typically a one-time process without iteration.
Most models consist of selecting techniques, executing the model, and diagnosis.
Presenting findings is the final step of the data science process.
The research goal should be vague to allow flexibility in the project.
Project charters require teamwork and input from multiple stakeholders.
Data marts are subsets of data warehouses serving specific business units.
Twitter, LinkedIn, and Facebook do not provide data for commercial use.
Data transformation is unnecessary if the data is already clean.
Exploratory data analysis is about cleansing data, not exploring it.
All modeling techniques can handle missing values without issues.
The outcome of step 1 should include well-defined deliverables.
Data retrieval always involves designing a data collection process from scratch.
Documentation and metadata are always the top priority in organizations.
Getting access to data within organizations is always quick and easy.
Correcting data errors should be done as early as possible in the process.
During exploratory analysis, you should keep your mind closed to avoid bias.
20% of techniques will help in 80% of cases according to the Pareto principle.
Presenting findings is an exciting part where you explain results to stakeholders.
Data can be stored only in databases, not in simple text files.
A project charter should include proof that the project is achievable.
